lines.text: [the cops aim their guns at Gil as he holds a knife in the stance of a pitcher on the pitcher's mound]
No! No, don't shoot! He's got my son!.
Now do you care? Bobby! Now do you care? Just a little bit?
[Gil picks out what tie to wear from his collection of ties]
Lucky tie, lucky guy.
[Gil talks to his son while listening to Mick Jagger in his van]
I remember when Mick recorded this in '78, we had a wild party afterwards.
Jason Pelligrino's dad says Mick Jagger's gay.

[Gil sarcastically replies]
Yeah? Well, Jason Pelligrino's dad takes it up the ass.
[Leon the bartender and Gil talk to each other after Bobby Rayburn walks into the bar]
What a waste of space.
What do you mean, 'A waste of space'? He hit a bad patch. We all hit bad patches, don't we? What you never hit a bad patch?

[Leon sarcastically replies]
No, this is my dream job.
[first lines]

[Gil narrating his poem]
Excited and anxious, I await my dream / To escape, applaud and embrace my team / Opening day I always can trust / It's just for this high that I crazily lust / Return of our hero does brighten the days / Just briefly my troubles get lost in the haze / The grace from the field arouses the crowd / Reflects on the days when I was quite proud / I'm more entranced than the average fan / I used to play, you see, and I know I still can / That time I drove the ball with such loft / My exit atop shoulders as they carried me off / This pastime and I just fade into one / Expanded upon from father and son / My boy is young and awkward for now / I just need the time and can show him how / I really am quite close, just a break away / From straightening things out and being okay / I can help my team to regain its glory / With just a little twist to the same old story / Players say now they play for themselves / This causes a burning within me that dwells / The fan is the one who pays for the game / Which bestows all the riches and welcomed fame / The players will listen but really don't hear / All the while just hiding behind an invisible tear / I grow tired now of all this greed / And chart a course to set things free
[Bobby talks to Gil about how the fans of baseball are losers]
At least you're not one of those diehard, you know, baseball fans. You know, really.
Why's that?
Because those guys are losers.
Aren't the fans what it's all about?

[Bobby chuckles]
Shit! Tell you somethin', man. The fans are like women. When you're hitting, they love you. When you're not, they'd just as soon spit on you as look at you.
Why is that?
Because they don't understand that you're the same person when you're hitting or not. No. The only person you should play for is yourself.
[Gil swings the bat to Coop's face, hitting him again in the head when he's down]
We could've been teammates. We were teammates, man. We could've made it to the Bigs.

[Coop bloody from the ground]
It was Little League. We were 12 years old.
[as Gil raises the bat up in complete rage, swinging it to Coop's head]
[Gil teaches his son about the sacrifice fly ball while watching the game]

Don't get greedy, son. Don't get greedy. What we need now is a sacrifice. A winning team has to know how to manufacture runs. Coop taught me that. He used to say the most beautiful play in the game is a sacrifice fly. You know why?
'Cause you give yourself up for the team?
And it doesn't even count against your average. That's why baseball's better than life. It's fair.
[Gil confronts Primo about Bobby needing the number 11 back]

Can I just say something? Did you ever think how one man who's doing well... might throw off the rest of the team? What I'm saying is, like, you have to think what's best for the team, right? You might have to lay down a sacrifice. I'm talking about Bobby Rayburn's number. I don't know if you really understand how much he needs that number. Number 11.
I am number 11.
I know, but he needs it more than you.
[Primo shows Gil the number 11 that's branded on his shoulder]
[Gil talks to Bobby on the phone after he kidnaps Bobby Rayburn's son]
Don't you talk back to me. You show me some respect. Without people like me, you're nothing. We're the ones that get you your 40 fuckin' million!
Look, what do you want?
What do I want? I want every time they think of you they're gonna think of me.
[Gil see's the old lady sitting behind his son staring at them both]
What's your fuckin' problem?

[the lady keeps staring at Gil]
You old busybody!
[Bobby Rayburn on the television answers a reporter's question about why he's now suddenly hitting]

[to the reporter]
I wish I knew.

[as Gil talks to the television]
That's it? You wish you knew. A simple thank you would have been nice.
[Bobby and the rest of the Giants team mourn Primo's death, as one player says to Bobby while pointing at the sleeve of his jersey]
Now we all get to wear the number, man.
[Gil meets the customer Stanley Jackson, who asks him for kayaks]
You got any kayaks?
You gotta be out of your fuckin' mind, kayaks?
I could use kayaks.
Stanley, what the fuck do kayaks have to do with knives?
Never mind.
You fuckin' asshole, kayaks you're asking me about when I'm asking you about knives?
Yeah. I understand, sir. Thank you for coming in.
How about you take some kayaks and stick 'em up your fuckin' ass, you moron.
[Jewel continues to bug Manny to get an exclusive with Bobby Rayburn]
You're saying there's absolutely no way you can get your boy to talk to me? Is that what you're saying? He's gotta talk to me.
I'm saying he'd rather nail his penis to a burning building, is what I'm saying, okay?

[Manny continues to talk on the phone]
No, I'm not talking to you, I'm talking to her.
[Bobby takes his first photo with Juan Primo as both men whisper in each others ears]

[with a smile]
I hope you like it in center field.

[with a smile]
Yeah, I hope you like it in left.
[Gil holds his knife while walking back to the pitcher's mound]

[to Bobby]
I never got to show you my best pitch.
[Gil turns around to see himself on the jumbotron, making a pitcher's stance]
[Bobby finds his son in the old dugout of where Gil used to play]
I love you, Sean.
I love you, dad.

[Bobby yells out to the cops]
I got him! I got him!
[Jewel and Manny talk for the first time at the Giants ballpark]
Well, well, well. If it isn't Jewel, my favorite token female sports reporter.
Blow me, Manny.
Yeah, I would, but you haven't had all your shots, babe.
[Manny tries to tell Bobby Rayburn to come out of the game before he injures himself worse]
I'm telling you, that media will turn on you faster than the fans. Listen to me, you gotta come out, okay?
I can't come out. On account of you, I gotta be Babe fuckin' Ruth!
It's William fuckin' Bendix! Can you get it right!
[Gil is fired from his job for his crazy behavior and lack of sales]
My father started this business.
Look, perfection and principles, they don't belong in business. Not now or then. As a friend of your father's...
As a friend of my father - Keep your mouth shut. You know nothing about my father.

[Gil sits down]
He made this business.
Your father made beautiful knives. San Francisco made this business.
Yeah, by ripping him off.
He wasn't a business man, Gil. And neither are you. That's the bottom line.

[voice on the radio]
... and so in a Freudian sense, Jewel, the catcher is the father, and the son is the pitcher.

[voice on the radio]
Wow, that's fascinating, Doc. Let me ask you a question. What does that bat and ball represent?
Well, the the bat speaks for itself, of course, and the ball is the ejaculate.

[in a dismissive tone]
Well, thanks for calling, Doc. Who do we have on Line Two, Bernie?
[Gil in front of his son's major tryouts, tells his son one thing while looking like a crazy man]

[Richie cries when telling his father]
Dad, you'd better go.
Don't swing at anything. Don't swing at anything. Wait for a good one. Step on the eggshell and squash the bug. Okay?

[Gil begins to walk off as he points to Tim]
You mind your fuckin business! You're lucky.
[Bobby talks to Jewel in his interview over the phone]
My season is like a bad freeway accident. And you guys, you're just slowing down to watch.
[Bobby tries to explain to Gil his newfound philosophy on baseball]

I mean, come on. Let's be real here, you know. What are we doin'? We're not curing cancer, you know? We're playin' a game. That's all it is. It's just a game. So I stopped caring and relaxed. Then I started hitting.
[Gil makes his threatening phone call to Bobby Rayburn]

Remember that kid in chemo... whose life was unfair to him. Well, that's the way I've been feeling - My life has been unfair to me. The only difference is I'll be able to see you hit that home run at the game tomorrow. And I got a photo here, and I'm gonna get it to you, and I want you to put it on the jumbotron, okay?
Yeah.
And what I want you to do, Bobby, is I want you to stand up and tell the 50 million viewers is that this home run is dedicated to Gil, a true fan. What do you think?
I can't believe you're serious.

I'm as serious as a heart attack, Bobby. That's pretty serious, isn't it? You know there comes a time in everybody's life, Bobby, when you have to stand up for somethin'. Otherwise, you're just passin' on through. So, Bobby, I'm watchin' you. And if that pitcher goes easy on you, I'm gonna kill your fuckin' kid. Surprise, surprise. Hey, Bobby!
I'm still here.

[Gil smiles before hanging up]
Now do you care?
[Gil tells Coop he's surprised he didn't move up in the baseball ranks]
I always thought you'd be managing by now, Coop?
Managing?
Yeah, in the Majors.
No one calls me Coop anymore, you sick son of a bitch.
[Bobby and Gil meet for the first time as Bobby asks him to guess who he is]
You like baseball?
Well, I'm not obsessed with it or anything. Are you a player?
Yeah. Yeah.
You are?

[Bobby smiles]
Yeah.

[Gil stares at Bobby for a second]
Barry Bonds?
[Gil tries to watch the game as he's running late, when the umpire calls time]
Time!

[Gil yells out]
Come on, let's play some fuckin' baseball!
[Gil holds up two of his knives to one of his customers]

[Gil with a smile on his face]
Big motherfucker. Little motherfucker. Which motherfucker do you want?
[Bobby and Gil start to argue about what life is about]
Look, all I'm saying is there's more to life than just baseball.
Like what? Like your house? Like your big ass car? Like your 40 fucking' million? I mean, what the fuck do you care about?
I care about my son. That's what I care about.
I'm sorry. I just hate that attitude you stopped caring. I'm sorry.
What? You got a better theory?
Yeah, you got your number back.
[Gil takes a bat and begins to head down to his son in the batters box]

[Gil looks for a bat talking to himself]
Look at this, the bat is too heavy.

[Tim tries to stop Gil from going on the field]
Come on.

[Gil turns around and holds the bat up at Tim]
Don't fuck with me! I'll send your head into the outfield!
[Bobby waits for that pitch to hit a home run on, when the opposing team begins pitching him balls]
What, are you walkin' me?
Consider it a compliment, dickhead.
Fuck! Do you know what you're doin' to me?
[Jewel waits to get Bobby Rayburn on the phone]
You got Bobby Rayburn on the line yet?

[the technician shakes his head no]
Who the fuck does this guy think he is?
Three time National League MVP?
And that gives him the right to fuck up my show?
[Gil's boss Mr. Garrity shows Gil and his staff a demonstration of just how great their knives are]

[Garrity drops a car door on the meeting desk]
Me, I think this knife is an ass kicker.
[Garrity then stabs the car door twice, then repeatedly over a dozen times]

[Garrity screams with the final stabs when he stops]
This door, on the other hand, comes off a foreign car. Well, need I say more?

[Garrity wipes the knife down looking back up to his staff]
What are you guys still doing here?
[Bobby argues with Manny over needing to be number 11]
I'm not playing with number 33. Okay, you understand me?
I know. I understand. Just be cool. Let me take care of it.
You know, three times 11 is 33. Maybe you'll play three times better.
[as Manny walks the Giants staff member away]
[Manny tries to make Bobby feel better about his new number 33]
Look, Jesus Christ was 33 when he died. People are still talking about him.
Jesus Christ? Give me my damn number!
[Gil gives a demonstration to a customer by shaving the hair off his legs with one of his knives]
Any more of these demos and I'm gonna have to start shaving the hair off my ass.
[Gil holds up a knife to sell, as the customer doesn't respond]

[Gil looks at the customer]
Knife doing business with you.
[Bobby takes some practice swings in the batting cage as he hits one out]
Poetry in motion, baby.
[Manny tells Bobby about seeing the sick kid in the hospital]
Spalding wants you to sign their balls. Before that we got that Wish Upon a Star routine. Sick kid in the hospital wants to shake hands with great baseball player.

[Manny sarcastically then says]
You'll have to do.
[Gil tells a scalper who sells him over-priced tickets what he hates most about scalpers]
You know what bugs me about guys like you?
Like I care.
You don't even care about the game.
[Bobby talks to the dying sick kid in the hospital]
What's your name?
Sean.
Sean? Sean.

[Bobby looks at Manny before replying]
Wow, what a coincidence. That's m-my son's name, too. Look, I have a present for you. Th-there you go. Maybe it'll make you feel better.

[Sean's father holds the bat up to his son, whispering]
Wow. Bobby Rayburn.

[Sean looks to Bobby]
Tomorrow, hit a home run for me? Please?

[Bobby quietly replies]
I'll try.
[Bobby finds out from Manny that he has to pay Primo $500,000 for his number 11 back]
Exactly. That's 250 G's a digit.
Oh, man, come on. What is this boy smokin'?
Look, I tried to haggle them down. I called the kid myself, and he says it's his lucky number.
Luck? Shit, there ain't that much luck in the world. He's lucky to be in the fuckin' country!
[Gil picks up his son and says hi to Ellen's boyfriend]
Hey, Gil.
Hey, Ted. Lose your job?

[Tim smiles]
It's my day off. And it's Tim.
[Gil asks his son where he got his baseball glove from]
Where'd you get that glove?
Tim gave it to me.

[Gil looks away]
It's a piece of shit.
[the Sports Reporters announce the opening day game]

Opening day at Candlestick Park, 1996. Steve, what's not to love about opening day? Fathers sneaking away early from work and kids playing hooky from school. You know, for at least one day, everybody's in first place.
Opening day is what baseball is all about. How exciting is it gonna be for Giants fans with Bobby Rayburn coming home... after leading the Braves to a championship.
[Gil and his son Richie arrive at the Giants game as Gil watches Bobby Rayburn do his practice swings]
Did you see that? Did you see the way he moved his legs?
Can I have a hot dog?
A what?
Can I have a hot dog?
[Manny calls Jewel a castrating ball buster]
Bernie, correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't she the castrating ball buster who had the temerity to ask my client if he was honestly worth 40 million?

[Jewel turns to Bernie]
Am I a ball-buster?
Yeah.
Thank you!
[Jewel sees a soda can in front of her and takes a drink out of it]
Whose is this?
It's mine. I spit in it.
[Jewel quickly spits the soda out]
[the ball park witnesses the bad collision between Bobby Rayburn and Juan Primo]

[Gil tells his son as both players are slow to get up]
Center field makes the calls. Fundamental of baseball. Center field makes the calls. Pay attention!

[the sports reporter announces]
Well, a scary moment on day one. Boy, I'll tell ya. Rayburn's slow getting up, and Primo's still slow getting up. Forty million dollars laying out there in center field, Steve. Hope the Giants have comprehensive collision coverage.
[Manny checks on Bobby while the doctor checks him out after the bad collision]
Doc, is the rib bruised or fractured?

[Bobby painfully replies]
Neither
[Gil runs over his son's leg to try and catch a foul ball]

[Gil tries to take the ball out of the kids' hand who does catch it, walking back to his seat]
The wind took it. The wind took it. Kid was lucky. Kid was lucky.

[Gil to his son]
The wind took it.
You stepped on me.
Don't worry. We'll get one next time.
[Jewel points out how Bobby Rayburn looks hurt after his bad collision]
Rayburn look like he's moving a little stiff to you?
I can't believe Burrows left him in their after that collision.
Oh, that's right. That's all we need - Our 40 million dollar man on the DL.
[Gil points out to his son how Bobby Rayburn is playing hurt]
Look at that, he's playing hurt. That's a man showing his mettle, putting the team first. And remember, last year he hit .314 against lefties.

[Gil yells out]
Yo, Bobby!
[Gil in front of his son yells at the umpire when he calls a strike on Bobby]
Strike!

[Gil yells out, standing up]
Are you out of your mind, Ump? Are you out of your fuckin' mind!
[Gil shows up to his appointment while leaving his son at the ball game alone, only to find out the owner had left]

[Gil looks at her in silence]
Um, but he did leave you this note.

[Gil opens the note]
He didn't draw a smiley face, did he?
What?

[Angie chuckles]
The previous assistant got him in the habit of drawing this little smiley face instead of 'sincerely,' and I keep telling him it's not always appropriate.
No.

[Gil slams the note back on her desk]
It's perfectly appropriate!
[Gil gets in the way of a fan in the row behind him and almost starts a fight]

[the man behind Gil taps Gil's shoulder]
Hey, hey!

[as Gil pushes him]
Take your hands off me!
Hey, stop pushin', man!
All right, just ask.
Who the fuck you pushin'? I'm askin'!

[as a man two rows back screams]
Hey, you! Both of you! Down in front!

[Gil flips off the man two rows back]
Ah, fuck you.
Down in front, now!
[Gil and the man behind him sit down as the crowd claps]
[Bobby asks Manny if the sick kid in chemo ever saw the home run]
Oh, Bobby. Bobby, the kid didn't even see it. He slipped into a coma in the first inning and never pulled out. I'm sorry.
How come you didn't tell me that, man?
Like you take bad news really well, huh? What am I supposed to say? 'Hey, I got great news. The kid didn't make it. Have a good one.'
[Manny congratulates Bobby on being back after that scary collision, hitting a home run]
You knocked the goddamn cover off that ball. You're back!
The hell I did. It was a fluke. I never even saw the pitch.
[Gil talks to his son Richie about his little league]
Think I'll make the Majors?
Positive things happen to positive thinkers. Who said that?
Coop.
Damn straight. And he was the greatest player I ever played with.
[Manny finally agrees to do the Bobby and Jewel interview]
You still want that interview?
Are you serious? You would let Bobby Rayburn do an interview with a - What was it?

[Bernie answers]
Castrating ball buster.
Castrating ball buster, that's right. I thought I was off your list, man.
Come on, Schindler has a list, not me. Okay? When you're hitting .183, you don't get a chance to have a list.
[Bobby talks to Jewel over a drink about his career slump]
I think the slump is a good thing.
Now, what kind of twisted shit is that?
It's gonna teach you to cut yourself a little slack. You can't keep up this act forever.
Oh, now it's an act now.
Oh, yeah. Mr. Perfect, Mr. No Error. Nobody can live up to that shit. You gotta give yourself a break. It's just a lie anyhow.
Yeah. Doesn't seem like a lie when I'm hitting.
[Leon the bartender points to Juan Primo sitting in the club, talking to Gil]
I wish we had a whole team like him!

[Gil replies after looking back at Primo]
Fuckin' asshole.
[Gil talks to Bobby Rayburn on the phone over Jewel's live radio station]

[to Bobby]
Listen, I wanna tell you that I know exactly what you're going through, more than you'll ever understand. You know, this whole number 11 thing is, is a fuckin' joke! I mean, you're the greatest player this city has ever had. And all of a sudden you've got... some flash in the pan, some hotdogger like Primo giving you a hard time about your number. I mean, you're the star. There's a reason you're being paid 40 million. And on top of it, the owners aren't even doing what they should be doing. I mean, they should be protecting their investment. I mean, pay him whatever he wants! Give him whatever he wants! If he wants a million dollars, give it to him. And if he doesn't want to take a million dollars, and if he doesn't want to give up his number, then fuck him! Get him out! What the fuck is the difference? Just get you hitting again. If that's what it's gonna take, then that's what it's gonna take.
And they say the fans don't know what they're talking about. You know, I think the public and the owners should be listening to you, Gil. And Bobby, why isn't this guy on your payroll?
[Bobby starts to feel guilty for Primo's death as he talks to Manny]
You know, Bobby. I wish five people dead on my drive to work everyday; five people. But wishing doesn't make it so, Bobby. You're not God, lifetime averages withstanding.
Yeah? Well, why do I feel so bad then, huh?

I don't know. I don't... you know, this is gonna blow the hell out of my shithead theory. But I think you feel guilty. Oh, Jesus Harry Christ. You know, I've been wrong about you all these years. You're not a shithead at all. I'm fucking flabbergasted.
[Bobby tells Gil his reason for getting out of a slump]
You know, Curly, I just stopped caring, man.
What?
I just stopped caring.
You stopped caring? What do you mean?
Hey, man, all my life I've been working to be the best. You know? Trying to be a perfectionist. And I thought about it, that's probably where I made my mistake.
[Bobby shakes Gil's hand after their little game of baseball, when Gil doesn't let go]

[Gil smiles]
Come on. Admit it. We're alone.
Admit what?
Admit you're hitting because Primo's not around.
Oh, that's a bunch of bullshit.
It doesn't hurt that he's not around. Come on. Level with me.

[as Gil's expression becomes more serious]
Level with me. Come on, I saved your kid. You wanna pay me back? Be honest with me and tell me you're happy that he's dead. Just a little.
[Bobby checks his freezer while on the phone with Gil, as Bobby finds the cut out piece of flesh of Juan Primo's number 11 tattoo]

[Gil laughs]
He finally figures it out ladies and gentleman. Boy, it's really true what they say about sluggers - They are really, really stupid. Well, I'm a pitcher, Bobby. And pitchers use their brains.
[Coop gets nervous after Gil makes that threatening phone call to Bobby]
You're getting some serious shit for that. Cops are gonna be all over us.
Boy, all of a sudden you lost your sense of humor.
[Gil begins to pitch the ball to Bobby Rayburn's son Sean, as Sean grows afraid]

[Gil begins to yell more louder]
Come on, bring the bat up slugger. Come on, look like a hitter. Bring it up. Bring it up. Bring it up. Come on. Come on! Come on, slugger. Bring the fuckin' bat up. Come on.

[Sean brings up the bat with tears down his eyes, as Gil smiles]
That's my boy.
[Gill calls into Jewel's radio station at the final big game]
This is gonna be one of the most amazing nights in the history of the game, believe me. It's gonna be incredible.
Really? Why is that, Gil?
I'm telling you, The Kirk Gibson homer, Ripkin breaking Gehrig's record. Peanuts compared to tonight.
You're talkin' about some classic moments in baseball history. Well, what's gonna happen tonight that could top those?
Let's just say, Bobby Rayburn is in for the night of his life.
Why's that, Gil?
'Cause some people are ungrateful, and they should be taught a lesson.
[the sports announcer calls the final play of Bobby Rayburn's hit]

[announcing, as the pitcher let's the ball go]
San Diego protecting its one-run lead. Martinez readies, steadies and delivers to...

[Rayburn hits the ball deep]
Rayburn drives it deep to right center field.

[the ball hits the wall]
It's off the wall. Rayburn could get three if he hustles. Robinson having trouble just getting to the ball.

[Rayburn keeps circling the plates]
Rayburn, rounding second, headed for third. And he's running through the stop sign. This could be an inside-the-park home run. The relay from Parker.

[Rayburn slides for home plate]
Rayburn slides head first! And he is... in there!

[the crowd cheers with Jewel]
Yes!

[as the disguised umpire Gil says]
You're out!
[Bobby continues to ask Gil where his son Sean is]
Bobby, where's my home run?
What? Curly, Curly. Where's my son?

[Gil chuckles]
Where is he? I don't know. I guess he's in that big stadium in the sky.
[last lines]

[we see the images of trophies, news clippings, and baseball memorabilia within the dugout of where Gil used to play at, as a news reporter narrates]
What you are seeing here is a sad turn of events, indeed. Gil Renard, an unemployed knife salesman, was shot to his death by the police during tonight's game. Here's how it happened - Bobby Rayburn.
